BobNelson2

Poll finds U.S. warming to gay marriage
 Opposition off 12% since '04 -- support for adoption, military role is up nationally
 
 http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2006/03/23/MNGAOHSE4I1.DTL
 Opposition to same-sex marriage dropped sharply across the country during the past two years, though just over half of Americans still oppose allowing gays and lesbians to marry, according to a poll by the Pew Research Center released Wednesday.
 That's a remarkable improvement over the last two years. It's not really surprising. People can see that marriage in Massachusetts hasn't brought ruin.
 
 The continuing problem, of course, is that most people don't vote, so the GOP tactic of demonizing gay people will continue to drive those opposed to same-sex marriage to the polls in disproportionate numbers.
 
 Still, it's good news on several issues.

The point of my initial post (besides presenting the lastest polling data) is that those opposed to same-sex marriage are just barely a majority. Of those, many are reflexively opposed (just as some are reflexively in favor). 
 
 The difference between polling and voting data is that the most rigidly opposed are more likely to vote because the GOP stirs them up (intentionally). And, mostly, because MOST people don't vote -- pretty pathetic in a democracy, but whatchagonnado? 
 
 Gay people DO need to figure out how to counteract that group's disproportionate influence. And, yes, that group -- or at least a significant part of it -- IS bigoted, IS anti-equality, and IS composed of true homophobes.
jyoshu

The difference between polling and voting data is that the most rigidly opposed are more likely to vote because the GOP stirs them up (intentionally).

Well its good news and bad news...
 It isn't really that big of a jump because '04 was a peak that didn't follow the normal trend. If you look at the numbers for before and after '04 then its more or less the same slow trend toward acceptance.
 
 - Jyoshu, whilst in some cases that will be true there is a reason there is so much focus on these sort of issues (abortion, gay marriage etc) is that its a lot easier to motivate voters into voting on something fairly simple and completely opposed to the opponent than trying to convince them that your plan to improve the economy, schools and healthcare is more efficient and likely to succede than the opponents plan to improve the economy, schools and healthcare.
